facts.text: Petitioner owns Urrunabund Tea Estate in village Udarbund, District of Cachar, State of Assam.

anchor.surface_text: The Petitioner owns a tea estate called the Urrunabund Tea Estate in village Udarbund in the District of Cachar in the State of Assam.

facts.text: Tea Estate extent is about 2682 acres.

anchor.surface_text: The extent of the Tea Estate is about 2682 acres.

facts.text: Out of the area, 553.73 acres are under tea cultivation.

anchor.surface_text: Out of the said area, 553.73 acres are under tea cultivation and the rest, according to the Petitioner, is utilis

facts.text: Rest of the area is utilised for purpose of tea industry and purposes connected with it, according to petitioner.

anchor.surface_text: - affidavit that the remaining area is lying fellow and unutilised. On December 4,1959, the Deputy Commissioner of Cachar at Silchar, respondent No. 2 issued a numberification requisitioning

facts.text: Deputy Commissioner of Cachar at Silchar, respondent No. 2, issued notification on December 4, 1959 requisitioning 183 bighas of land of the Tea Estate.

anchor.surface_text: On December 4,1959, the Deputy Commissioner of Cachar at Silchar, respondent No. 2 issued a numberification requisitioning an area of 183 bights of land of the said Tea Estates, and by

facts.text: Deputy Commissioner issued another notification dated December 5, 1959 requisitioning 149 bighas 19 kathas and 11 chattacks of land of the Tea Estate.

anchor.surface_text: another numberification dated December 5, 1959, he requisitioned another extent of 149 bighas 19 companytahs and 11 chattacks of land of the said Tea Estate. The petitioner filed two

facts.text: Petitioner filed two petitions in this Court under Art. 32 praying for writs of mandamus directing respondents to forbear from giving effect to the requisition orders.

issues.text: Whether tea industry is a matter for exclusive legislation by Parliament under Entry 52, List I of the Seventh Schedule to the Constitution, rendering the Assam Land Requisition and Acquisition Act of 1948 ultra vires the State Legislature insofar as it provides for requisition and acquisition of tea estates or lands appertaining thereto?

anchor.surface_text: i  tea industry is a matter for exclusive legislation by the Parliament under Entry 52, List I of the Seventh Schedule to the Constitution,, and therefore, the Assam Land  Requisition and Acquisition , Act of 1948, hereinafter called the Act , in so far as it provides for the requisition and acquisition of a tea estate or lands appertaining,to it, is ultravires the State Legislature

issues.text: Whether the Assam Land Requisition and Acquisition Act of 1948 is constitutionally void under Article 31(2) of the Constitution as it does not provide for payment of compensation for requisitioned property or specify the principles and manner for determining such compensation?

anchor.surface_text: ii  the said Act is also constitutionally void as it offends Art. 31 2  of the Constitution, inasmuch as it does number. either provide for payment of companypensation for the property requisitioned or specify the principles on which and the manner in which companypensation is to be determined.

holdings.text: A companyparative study of both the Acts makes it clear that the two Acts deal with different matters and were passed for different purposes. The Tea Act in numbersense of the term can be described as one altering, repealing or amending the Act passed by the Assam Legislature. This companytention is, therefore, rejected.

anchor.surface_text: A companyparative study of both the Acts makes it clear that the two Acts deal with different matters and were passed for different purposes. The Tea Act in numbersense of the term can be described as one altering, repealing or amending the Act passed by the Assam Legislature.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assam Act concerns land requisition and acquisition for public purposes like essential supplies; Tea Act regulates tea industry development, cultivation, export without addressing land requisition; no express or implied repeal; Tea Act s.15(1)(b) contemplates acquisition under other laws including requisition implicitly.

holdings.text: These provisions provide for the payment of agreed companypensation, and, in the case of disagreement between the Collector and the person. to whom possession of any land is delivered under s.6, for a reference to the Court. In respect of any such reference to the Court, the, provisions of the land Acquisition Act, 1894, shall mutatis mutandis apply.

anchor.surface_text: These provisions provide for the payment of agreed companypensation, and, in the case of disagreement between the Collector and the person. to whom possession of any land is delivered under s.6, for a reference to the Court. In respect of any such reference to the Court, the, provisions of the land Acquisition Act, 1894, shall mutatis mutandis apply.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sections 7 and 8 of Assam Act provide agreed compensation or court reference on disagreement; LAA 1894 applies mutatis mutandis to such references, supplying principles and manner for determination as required by Art.31(2).

holdings.text: We do number see any difficulty in applying those principles for paying companypensation in the matter of requisition of land. While in the case of land acquired, the market value of the land is ascertained, in the case of requisition of land, the companypensation to the owner for depriving him of his possession for a stated period will be ascertained.

anchor.surface_text: We do number see any difficulty in applying those principles for paying companypensation in the matter of requisition of land. While in the case of land acquired, the market value of the land is ascertained, in the case of requisition of land, the companypensation to the owner for depriving him of his possession for a stated period will be ascertained.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Mutatis mutandis application of LAA ss.23-25 to requisition by substituting 'requisition' for 'acquisition' and 'market value of possession interest deprived' for 'market value of land'; avoids legislative incongruity between acquisition and requisition compensation.

holdings.text: For the aforesaid reasons, we reject this companytention. No other point is raised.

anchor.surface_text: For the aforesaid reasons, we reject this companytention. No other point is raised.

anchor.surface_text: We do number see any difficulty in applying those principles for paying companypensation in the matter of requisition of land. While in the case of land acquired, the market value of the land is ascertained, in the case of requisition of land, the companypensation to the owner for depriving him of his possession for a stated period will be ascertained.
